segments.text: This is an interview with Sergeant First Class Lee Westbrook by Norah J. Garza on the 5th of December, 1988, at his home and college station concerning the Vietnam War.
Right.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
That'll go with you.
That's fine.
Okay.
Let's start the questions with basic, your date and place of birth.
I was born on March 11, 1941, in Southern Springs, Texas.
My father was a seismographer with Magnolia Oil Company.
He moved around a lot.
We settled not too long after that in his former home of Gainesville, Texas, which is where I more or less grew up off and on.
over the next 17 years.
I've lived all over the United States prior to joining the Army.
My dad moved around a lot.
And when I was 17, I joined the Texas National Guard.
And when I was 18, I joined the regular Army and I left.
And except for a few visits, I haven't been back since.
OK, which takes care of our next question.
Any of your educational background?
I quit high school and joined the Army.
Two years later, I got a GED when I learned how to spell it.
And in 1970, the Army sent me to the University of Southern California, and I are an aerospace safety engineer.
So I've got some college background, and I have a course completion in aerospace safety engineering, which is accident investigation or anything else.
Pretty much self-taught and everything else.
And once I settled down and quit being a wild-eyed hell-raiser, I started to educate myself.
I'd like to go through a brief sketch of your military career before being known.
That's going to be hard to do because it wasn't brief.
It was eight years long, and it had 22 different assignments in it.
But I try to encapsulate it as much as I can.
I originally enlisted in the regular army to be an MP.
I started out in National Guard as a Browning automatic rifleman in the armored calf squadron.
And I liked it, but I wanted to be an MP.
I had some things wrong with one of my ankles.
They were very strict in those days.
I got busted out of the MP school and went to medical training.
It was that or the infantry, and because of my ankle, they wouldn't let me go to the infantry.
I tried.
I tried to go airborne.
They wouldn't let me go.
So I became a medic, and that's pretty much what I did for the next eight years, that and trying to get out of the medical court.
I didn't even actually work as a medic in a hospital on a ward until I'd been a medic for almost seven years.
I did a tour in the Aleutian Islands where I didn't do my job, I did other jobs.
And when I came back from that, I went to Fort Knox, Kentucky.
assigned to a field hospital that was in reorganization.
They had been in Chile during the 1960 earthquakes down there, left all their equipment, most of the people were due to get out.
When they came back, they got out and they reorganized and rebuilt the unit.
I helped rebuild it.
About six, eight months later, I reenlisted for a reassignment in West California.
Spent nine months out there, was assigned to Germany.
Came up on the levee.
Spent three years in Munich, Germany, driving an ambulance all over southern Bavaria.
Real tough job.
Loved it every second of it.
And I came back from Germany.
I went back to the San Francisco Bay Area, and that's where, for the first time, I worked in a hospital on a ward.
It was one of the two most rewarding experiences of my life.
I worked with terror and quadriplegics.
Quite a few of them at that time in 1965 were Vietnam veterans.
We had 76 patients on the ward, 56 of them were Vietnam veterans.
And all of them were paralyzed to one extent or another.
I was trying to go to Vietnam because it seemed like the thing to do.
That's where the action was.
I was a pro.
And came up on levy for Germany again.
But in the meantime, I had applied for helicopter flight school.
and there was some difficulty with the paperwork.
I got levied for Germany, had to reapply.
I went back to Germany, and while I was there, I made staff sergeants and took over the battalion medical section.
It was an aviation battalion, as it were.
And I picked up a little bit of knowledge and information about helicopters and flying and some of the people there.
And I hadn't been there quite a year when...
I was accepted to flight school.
I accepted the nomination to flight school and left immediately.
I hadn't been home for Christmas since 1958.
This was 1966.
I made it home for Christmas by the skin of my teeth.
So that was the first of a while.
Nine months in flight school, which five months of it was at Fort Walters, Texas, best kept secret in the Army, and the remainder at Fort Rucker, Alabama,
And then I showed up in Vietnam two days before Tet 68 started.
What else do you want to know besides that?
That's very right.
I've got a question for you.
Were you married during this time before you went to Vietnam?
Yes, I got married about two and a half years after I joined the Army.
Still got the same wife.
That's to her credit, not mine.
She was a good lady.
So you said you went to Vietnam?
By the time I got to Vietnam, I'd been in the Army for almost 10 years.
Well, yeah, almost 10 years.
Okay.
My question was the fact that the Army tried to carry you, you know, like before Vietnam.
Right.
I made a few little notes here and wanted to refer to them.
All my previous training and all my professional thought, as it were, and the thought processes that I developed were geared to fighting and winning in combat.
By this stage in my career, my life,
I'd pretty much settled down, and I was trying to act like a professional soldier.
Took correspondence courses whenever I could.
Any training that came along, if I could get into it, I'd get into it.
Whatever I could to develop myself.
I was fairly single-minded in my thoughts that I wanted to be the best that I could be.
And doing this from a narrow field like I was, it's kind of hard to do.
which is why I broke out and went in a helicopter, one of the reasons why.
So my whole thought process was being a professional soldier.
The preparation for me wasn't specific toward Vietnam.
I don't think I ever saw any specific indoctrination, training, education, anything, on anything that was happening in South Vietnam.
I knew some things about Southeast Asia.
I had known for years about things.

I was familiar with Ho Chi Minh's original purposes there with the Viet Minh running the French out in 1954, the Battle of Dien Bien Phu, the tenacity of the people to carry in on their backs the parts and pieces to 105 howitzers, two-bar artillery.
That's a big gun.
And pack it in on their backs across mountains
and devastate the so-called fortress that Demian put.
The arrogance of the French to believe that it couldn't be done cost them their colonization.
So I knew something about that.
I knew a little bit about Orientals, just from what I picked up here and there.
It was a mishmash of information, just little bits and pieces here and there that added up to a whole, which wasn't very much.
I was no expert by any means.
But having spent a lot of my life
On the move, from one place to another, I learned how not to be an ugly American.
I'd read the book, knew what it said, and tried not to do it.
I wasn't your typical GI in Germany.
Close, but no cigar.
So when I got to Vietnam, I knew enough about it to begin to learn from that point on.
But it was all on my own.
The Army didn't prepare me for it at all.
Okay, I guess we'll go through your first tour first.
When you served it, where, how long?
Okay.
When I got there, just before Tet 68 started, literally hours, I didn't know where I was going to be assigned.
You went to the replacement depot, and you took what they gave you.
They wanted bodies that could do this, that, or the other, and they put them in the vacancies that had been created by one reason or another.
So I was assigned to the 17th Aviation Group, which was based in the train, and they further assigned me to the 52nd Combat Assault Battalion, which was based in Pleiku at the old French fort.
Holloway Army Airfield was the name of it.
They further assigned me to the 119th Assault Helicopter Company, which is where I stayed for about the first four months I was there.
And then they came up with a thing called the D-Row Shuffle.
It was a new unit in the battalion that was losing some of its old people, and they had to be replaced from within with other experienced people.
By that time, I had a little dab of experience, and they sent me to the 57th Assault Helicopter Company in Khantoum.
Khantoum was located about 40 miles north and a little bit west of Pleiku, and it was right at the foot of one of the branches of the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
It was an outlet.
Besides our unit,
There was one engineer company there and a special forces camp there.
And that was the extent of the American involvement in Khantoum.
Shortly after I got there, the engineers left.
And the special forces people were kind of aloof and standoffish to everybody.
They had the locals convinced they had an underground armored division that was kept in secret.
And if anybody ever did anything to them, they was going to turn them loose on the town and destroy it and kill everybody in it.
The fools believed it, but they very seldom ever got in trouble.
We used to get mortared and rocketed anywhere from three to five times a week, usually at two o'clock in the morning.
It was fairly well predictable.
So my duties there consisted of flying the missions in the mountains in support of elements of the 4th Infantry Division and that Special Forces camp.
We worked mainly small unit tactics against

regular north vietnamese units when and where we could find them and it was usually on the spur of the moment they would call a tactical emergency and we would three or four ships would meet someplace we would load up with troops get a quick briefing and join the assault we usually have a heavy gun team which consisted of three gunships as opposed to a gun team which is two gunships
And we would go do what it was that we do, which is put the troops on the place where they need to be.
Usually the side of a mountain or the top of it, rarely ever an open field.
If we could get an area that was big enough to get three ships into, that was rare indeed.
It was usually single ship landing zones or LZs.
You went in one at a time by yourself.
We had to be extremely careful because of these small landing zones.
If we did anything stupid and cracked up the aircraft, we just plugged up the LZ, and then nobody could get in or out.
So it got pretty hairy, and it required learning some skills that people said couldn't be done.
Well, in the process, we rewrote the book about what you could do with helicopters in the mountains.
We had good machines.
We had good men.
Primarily, though, it was small unit tactics against regular elements of the North Vietnamese Army.
and specifically the 408th North Vietnamese Sapper Battalion, or regiment, which was located in and around the countryside all around us.
We were completely surrounded by it.
Did that for the remainder of my tour, working there in Special Forces operations across the fence in Laos and Cambodia.
When LBJ said we weren't doing it,
and we carried those people over there so they could do what it was that they do, which was spy, assassinate, and kidnap.
We also resupplied their mountaintop radio relay stations and listening posts, kept those people out of trouble, fed, clothed, and rotated for R&R when they needed to, things like that.
It had its moments of excitement.
Most of the time it was fairly routine stuff, ash and trash, pigs and goats, chickens and oats, and just hauling stuff around and putting it off here and picking it up there.
Fairly well mundane, really.
The actual flying conditions were more treacherous than the combat conditions, except when the combat conditions really erupted.
At that stage of the game, we had established our air superiority.
And the bad guys had developed a fairly good respect for the fact that if they shot at one of our aircraft, we were going to hurt them.
And we were going to spend millions of dollars doing it.
We had the assets, we had the time, we had the place, and we had the motive.
And they knew we would do it.
And we did.
So they didn't take idle shots at us.
And usually when we did get shot at, it was...
We were enjoying in some kind of a battle of some sort.
That was pretty much what we did for the whole time there.
It was like the old Siemens chant of hours and hours of boredom interspersed with moments of stark terror.
And sometimes it got pretty scary.
This was from January 68 to January 69?
Right.
Which time you came on home?
I came home there.
Okay.
How did you feel about the war at this point?
At that particular stage of the game?
I mean, you'd been a veteran of the year and seen quite a bit, I'm sure.
Well, I made a few notes on that to try to keep it down to a dull roar here.
A guy once told me that
And I'll never forget it.
This is a dirty little war, but it's the only one we got.
Well, a lot of us lifers looked at it that way.

It was kind of a game more than anything else because it really didn't have drawn battle lines and, you know, General Rommel over there and whatever over there and pitched battles, tanks against tanks and so on.
It wasn't that way.
Most of the time it was just individuals against individuals.

he was right it wasn't during the war but it was the only thing we had but we sort of accepted the fact that us lifers that people get killed in wars and some of them might even be friends so that didn't really have that much bearing on how i felt i don't really think that i had a broad enough vision in those days to see what was going on around me
I know that there was a lot of frustration going on within myself.
I saw a lot of things done for nothing, it would seem.
Many times I saw us pay for the same real estate two and three times.
I saw friends get killed doing this.
It gets fairly ludicrous and it takes its toll on you no matter how motivated you are.
It's fairly clear to me now.
I really was on the horns of a dilemma and didn't recognize what it was all about.
I was just so single-minded in my thinking.
A strong part of my thinking was accomplish the mission, gung-ho, charge on.
And another part of me, equally as strong, was saying, this is a crock.
It's for nothing.
We're really blowing.
And each one of these conclusions was fighting for possession of them.
And no matter which one of them won, I was going to be the ultimate loser.
Well, I didn't realize that stuff in those days.
One of the things I've come to learn since then is that confusion is the mother of fear, and fear is the controller of attitudes, and mine went in the toilet.
Not that I didn't want to do it anymore or didn't care anything about doing it anymore.
If that was true, I'd have quit.
It went the other way.
I developed an arrogance about me to hide my fear, which I was afraid of itself.
I wasn't afraid to get killed or anything like that.
I was afraid of being afraid.
And I developed an arrogance that really got bad.
And the worse it got, the worse it got.
It became synergistic.
It just fed on itself.
By the time I got back for my second tour, I thought I had it figured out.
If I could just go back and do my job better this time, we'd win.
And I didn't know I was putting the blame on me.
I had no idea, none whatsoever.
But for the time being, it was what had to be done.
I was a soldier, professional.
This was my chosen way of life, and I was going to do it.
Like the man said, it was a dirty, nasty little war, which only we had.
Okay.
You said you went back for a second tour.
Let me change this a bit.
Was the decision to return to Vietnam yours?
No, not at all.
It was a given.
If you were a lifer, especially a helicopter pilot, the second tour was an automatic.
Some people even got a third tour.
depending on how early they started, and I kind of hit it just at the right time.
And that's, you know, it's not to say that I did or did not volunteer for it.
It was just something that was going to happen.
I spent my year and a half or so at home as a flight instructor out in Texas waiting for it to happen.
And that, too, was a bad thing because I never did relax because I knew I was going back.
And I knew that I could not afford to slack off in my thinking, my awareness of what was going on around me.
I developed a sense of awareness from those days that, looking back on it now, boggles my mind.
I became, through this fear thing, absolutely aware of absolutely everything going on around me and had the ability to take in a fact, analyze it, and discard it if it wasn't going to kill me.
And that's exactly the way I look at everything.
If it wasn't going to kill me, it didn't matter.
Ain't about nothing.
This is a famous expression from Vietnam.
Don't mean a thing.
I never relaxed.
I was still in Vietnam even though I was at home.
Because I knew when I went back, I could not afford to have to develop these senses all over again.
Because I would be expected to pick up right where I left off.
And I didn't have the sense enough to learn how to relax
So it wasn't really a matter of me volunteering or they sending me.
It was just that was the next step.
I don't think I would have chosen either way.
I just sat and waited.
And when the orders came, I packed up and went.
And I left two baby daughters behind me.
They're grown now.
Okay.
I was wondering if you could briefly describe your duties on the second tour.
Medevac.
I got assigned to the original dust-off detachment, 57th Med Detachment of Ambulance Helicopter.
Yeah, that's how it goes.
And they were the original dust-off unit that was started back in, I think, 1966.
Dust-off is an acronym, but for the life of me, I can't remember what it means anymore.
Maybe it's
Somebody you talk to one day is going to remember that they've got a big convention coming up next weekend down in San Antonio.
But I'm not going.
Primarily in 1971, we were involved in the medical evacuation of Arvids.
There were very few U.S. left in the Delta where I was assigned near Canto.
Elements of the 9th Infantry Division, some Navy,
few aircraft outfits, one cab squadron, air cab squadron, and they pretty much took care of their own folks.
But I was based there at Ben Tuohy at the Third Surge Hospital.
It was a MASH hospital.
I lived there, and the base was across the street at the Navy Airfield.
And that was primarily what we did, was picked up the little people and brought them in.
Most of the missions were at night.
Very few of them in the daytime.
And we covered an area of 12,000 square miles.
I learned some very hard lessons from some of those night evacuations about people, especially the originals.
I knew some things about them, but I had no idea until I did that tour.
But mainly it was just picking up the wounded, taking them to a hospital sometimes.
Okay.
You were saying that you learned some very hard lessons.
Would you like to relate any experiences that you feel, I'm sure the war as a whole did make a lasting impression on your life, that something that you feel just stood out?
Oh, several things that stood out.
I don't tell war stories.
I just don't do it.
But this one, I'm going to relate one incident.
It was deep night.
We were called way out somewhere to pick up this one Arvin that had been severely wounded.
He'd been shot by one of his fellows is what had happened.
And he was fragged.
Yeah, threw a hand grenade at him.
Something about a girlfriend and requited love and all that stuff.
But anyhow, we went out and picked the guy up.
And the medic we had on board was a kid named Randy Hill.
And he was from Tyler, Texas.
And he was 19 years old and did amazing feats of saving people's lives.
His ability and his skill and knowledge was just beyond my comprehension.
I don't know how he did it, but he did.
Well, he kept the guy alive, had IVs, intravenous injections, plugged into him just about everywhere he could.
Our control told us to take this chap to the pad at Mito.
Well, this particular pad is a very nasty one.
And Mito is a very nasty little village.
And it has some bad guys in it.
And we don't like to go there at night, but we had to go.
We called them way out, 20 minutes out, that we were coming in.
And we talked to the American advisor there, and he assured us that an ambulance would be standing by there at the pad next to the canal when we got in there.
And they would quick time get him off the ship so we could get out of there before somebody had a chance to draw a beat on us.
And about 10 minutes out, we called them back, confirmed that, yeah, they were trying to get that ambulance rounded up now.
And five minutes out, we called in, and they said, yeah, the ambulance is on its way to the pad.
And two minutes out, we called them and told them we were landing.
And when we got to the pad, no one was there.
We're sitting there, a great big 9,500-pound helicopter making a tremendous amount of noise with lights on.
We turned the lights off.
Nothing really did any good.
All you had to do was aim at the noise.
And we called them and said, where's the ambulance?
They said, it's on its way.
This guy's laying in the back, bleeding to death.
Randy's keeping him alive.
We call again a minute later and told them we've got to leave.
We'd already been sitting on the ground for over 60 seconds.
That's sticking it so far out in the street, it's pathetic.
We just didn't do that.
They implored us to stay a little bit longer, so we waited another minute.
And we had outlived our existence by then.
So they told us to set the guy off.
The ambulance would be there any second and get on out of there.
So we did.
We came back about three hours later, still in the middle of the night, with another one.
And the same guy was still laying there, dead or alive.
They never picked him up.
The Americans couldn't.
The Vietnamese wouldn't.
I knew for years that Orientals viewed life and death a lot differently than Occidentals did.
And I learned a thing or two about that.
It puts things into perspective.
But I never conceived that it was like that, that they would let their fellow lay there and bleed to death because they were too scared of driving in and standing and picking up.
I've never forgotten anything.
There's not much I wouldn't do at this stage of the game, or at least I like to think so, that if someone needed something, needed help,
I don't know where I would place limits on trying to do it.
I don't think I would.
Anything within my power to do, I would do.
Regardless of risk.
Regardless of cost.
I've done it a few times.
Some of them are pretty stupid things to do, but I've done it.
So I don't have any doubt about that, whether or not I would.
It's just when.
The single question in my mind is when's the next time?
That made a lasting impression on me.
They wanted everything from us, but they weren't willing to give anything, even from themselves.
That, I've never gotten rid of.
Next question.
I kind of missed a question here.
Your second tour, you were there from... Oh, from, let's see here.
April 1971 to March 1972.
I left a month earlier.
On the stretcher.
Almost made it.
Two years without a scratch, all of it.
What kind of wound did you...
I broke my kneecap.
Oh, nothing spectacular or heroic.
I got drunk and fell down the stairs.
Okay, um...
One of my other questions was what kind of reception you received when you did come home on either tour, if they were any different, because they were very different stages of the war.
Very good question, too, and easy to answer.
When I came back from the first tour, I got a really little incident that happened before I came back from the first tour.
I came back before I was supposed to come back.
In August 1967, I went on R&R to Hawaii,
I was originally scheduled to go to Hong Kong, and at the very last minute, I mean literally within hours of it, I changed and went to Hawaii because it was my oldest daughter's birthday.
She had written a letter and said, I wish my daddy could come home for his birthday.
How can you turn that down?
So I got a guy to swap with me, and I went to Hawaii, and they told us, don't go back to Kaunas, the United States.
No, you've been bad.
You stink.
Stay out of there.
They don't want you there.
Can't leave Hawaii.
And we all said bye, and then we all took off to the airport.
Well, I had to lay over in LAX, or Los Angeles International Airport, about 2 o'clock in the morning.
And I was in uniform with my wings and a few little ribbons that I possessed at that time.
The six-pack they give you for showing up were three-packs.
And I was standing at a kind of a stand-up hot dog stand.
A couple of maintenance guys were there, and this old gentleman that ran it was there.
And we were just shooting the breeze, and it wasn't even about the war.
And they were very polite not to say anything to me.
And we could hear this group and smell this group coming before we ever saw them.
There was about four or five of the scraggliest-looking hippies you ever saw in your life.
And they saw me, and they saw those silver wings, which to them equated to napalm and baby killing.
And they immediately zeroed in on me.
And they was all kinds of things, which I'm not going to repeat.
And accusing me of every vile crime in the world.
And these guys that were with me there, just standing there shooting the breeze, wanted to run them off.
And I said, no, wait a minute, I'm going to show you something.
I was having a good time.
And I stood there and I took it, nodded my head, okay, okay, anything else?
And finally they just flat ran out of steam.
They were yelling and hollering.
It's a wonder the police didn't show up, all the noise they were making.
And I just stood there and took it.
And I said, you know, folks, everything you said is absolutely true.

Furthermore, did you know, and I started making up some of the god-awfulest macabre stories that the mind can conceive, and one of them became physically ill, and some of the descriptions that I was giving of what we did, which we never did,
Two others just turned around and ran because they thought I was fixing to go berserk.
I get pretty wild-eyed sometimes, and I have green eyes, and they sparkle.
They light up, literally.
They look really weird, I've been told.
And I really had a blast at it.
They all kind of was backing away.
They didn't know whether I was going to pounce on them or what, and I was just trying to tell them.
I said, wait, come back.
There's more.
There's more.
You know, trying to really be their friend and all this stuff.
These guys just cracked up over it.
That was the only incident I ever ran into at that stage in the game, and I had a ball with it.
Absolute blast.
When I got home in January of 69, I have two rather wealthy uncles.
Well, one now.
They live in Dallas, and they wanted to take me out of the town in uniform.
That was the proviso.
So my wife and I, we got gussied up a little bit, and off we went.
And they took us to a real fancy joint where we stood in line for two hours to eat.
Well, I had gotten used to consuming copious amounts of scotch in those days, and these guys didn't know how to do that.
By the time we got to eat, they were fairly well gone, and I was just getting started.
There was no one said anything against me.
No one said anything to me either in the place.
I don't believe, I don't recall, but I know that it wasn't anything negative as such.
I noticed people looking at me, and they would look away when I caught their eye, but no one ever said or did anything.
The whole time that I was home, 1969 to 71, I was insulated and isolated from the rest of the world.
I was in Mineral Wells, Texas, in Fort Walters, a place that was very pro-army, pro-aviation,
We didn't have any hassles around there.
The locals wouldn't stand for it.
And the rest of the world didn't know we was there.
It wasn't one of your big bases like Fort Benning or Fort Knox where people knew where it was.
This was a little bitty place out on the edge of West Texas and no one knew it existed.
It was a great place.
Still is.
It's, for always, will be my home.
So I didn't get around all this stuff.
I watched the news and saw all the things that were going on, but I never got exposed to it personally.
When I went back to Vietnam in 1971, I knew about things happening, but I didn't know about them.
I wasn't educated about them.
I didn't want to be educated about them.
If I had my job, I was going to do it.
This was my job.
This is what I did.
And when I came back in 72,
That was different.
Enormously so.
I was medevaced back with a busted knee and spent some time in the hospital.
Spent some time on convalescent leave and was reassigned to Fort Hood, Texas.
Well, I decided to try to get away from the military for a while, at least see how the other half lived.
That was a mistake on my part.
I bought a house in Waco, 70 miles away.
Commuted every day, 140 miles a day.
And my neighbors put me through the mill.
I had one neighbor that would actually talk to me.
Nice old chap.
He didn't much care for the rest of them.
And he was the only one.
The rest of them, some of them wouldn't even let their kids play with mine when they found out who I was.
I left so early in the morning they never saw me, but when I came home in the evening, they did.
And there was no mistake in that flight suit.
Plus, it had the forehead stickers all over the car.
It was required.
And it didn't take long for the word to get around the neighborhood.
This guy's a Vietnam vet.
Those people would see me coming, would turn around and go back in their house.
That hurt.
It really did.
I got to where I did not tell people what I did for a living.
And as soon as I did,
instant turn off.
When I got out in 1973, for about a year, I did other things and then I went back to flying.
I was in Fort Rucker, Alabama as a civilian flight instructor for the Army.
And even around there, when you get away from the military complex itself, I didn't tell people what I did for a living.
In 1977, I went to work for an offshore
flying service in the Gulf of Mexico.
And I bought a house up north of Dallas.
And I had learned by that stage of the game not to tell people that I flew helicopters for a living.
And for a year and a half, none of my neighbors knew what I did.
They only knew that I was home a week and gone a week.
And one day, a chap that lived on one side of me, who I had shared many a beer over the fence with, chit-chatted about his
Capri and my old Chevrolet truck and talked this, that, and the other.
We're fairly good acquaintances.
We weren't hard and fast friends, but we were comfortable with each other.
One day his curiosity got the best of him.
And he asked me, he said, say, what do you do?
I said, what do you mean?
He said, well, you're here a week, you're gone a week.
You travel and sail, you don't look like one.
I thought about it for a second.
I said, why not?
Let's try it.
And I told him what I did, that I flew helicopters offshore in the Gulf of Mexico
in support of the offshore drilling industry.
And he looked at me and he said, one question.
Were you a pilot in Vietnam?
I said, yes.
The man never spoke to me again.
He was a young fellow, younger than I was.
I'd come out in the backyard, he'd go in the house.
And I endured that for 16 years.
Never quieted.
The guy on the other side of the house from me was a retired Navy.
One day he asked me what I did for a living.
And I just told him right straight out, and I said, and if you don't like it, pal, you can go to hell.
He said, I think it's great.
I was there, too.
The only one in the whole neighborhood, the two that knew what I did.
And pretty soon, it got all over the neighborhood that I was a Vietnam veteran helicopter pilot, a baby killer that dropped napalm on me.
Never killed anybody.
Never killed anybody that I know of.
It certainly didn't drop any napalm.
So there was a marked difference between the two homecomings, as it were.
And it steadily progressed from 1973 until 1984.
Things changed.
Things happened.
But it did get worse and worse and worse as it went along.
I read an article one time that a guy said that
We're taking our guilt out on the Vietnam veterans for what we allowed to go on unchecked.
And I think that made more sense than anything else.
The enormity of it is too much to avenge.
So I forgive them.
It's easier.
Does that answer your question?
Very well.
Good.
Going back to you, you said you did work with the Arvin on your second tour.
I've got a few questions, you know, relating to the people and the culture of South Vietnam.

I was wondering if you could, you know, briefly relate your view of the people, you know, how you felt, well, you have, but just to sum it up, your view of when you first got there, how it changed, you know, during, after the war, today, you know.
When I got there, they didn't change.
I did.
They're stoic.
They've been that way for thousands of years.
Vietnam has always been unsettled.
My youngest daughter gave me a book on Vietnam.
It's in the other room.
I think she bought it by the weight rather than the content.
It's about three inches thick, and it's the complete history of Vietnam for 4,000 years that was recorded.
And they had a recorded history 4,000 years long.
And it's been constant turmoil.
Well, when I got there, the people are simple people.
Very simple.
They're peasants.
They want a little piece of dirt.
They want to grow their food and live their life and raise their kids so that they can grow their food and live their life and raise their kids.
Very simple.
They're not all that ambitious.
The colonization by the French and the European influence on many of the families and dynasties in Vietnam
or what creates most of the turmoil.
The educated ones, they become ambitious.
There's nothing wrong with ambition.
Like what Mark Anthony said about it.
It's noble.
Nobody's going to let it go to your head.
But the simple people are just that.
They're simple people.
At the time,
Again, I have to emphasize, my vision was narrow.
I was a wiper GI all the way.
I didn't care about nothing but Army.
Didn't know anything but Army.
Didn't want to know anything but Army.
Soldier.
That was me.
All the way through.
With what I did.
And I tried to do it well.
But I saw these people just like any other people.
Except they didn't care what happened.
Because of the oriental mindset, what's going to happen is going to happen.
There's nothing you're going to do about it.
In some factions, they call it karma.
I don't know what they call it in others, but that's a pretty good handle on it.
It's going to happen.
It's going to happen.
We have very little influence over our destiny, is what they believe.
And they accepted things like that.
Yeah, they would mourn the dead and then go back to work.
We do the same thing.
We did exactly the same thing.
We buried my grandmother in 1976 or whenever it was.
We mourned that morning and partied that afternoon.
The uncle that was crying the most was partying the hardest.
So we're no different in that respect.
But the one thing I saw was that disturbed me and turned me against them was that
And I believe we were there righteously.
That's where I went wrong.
But we were trying to provide a service for them, and they didn't care whether they got it or not.
And I think that's where the Viet Minh and the VC had it over.
They found people who had been put down by the colonialism and by the ambitious rich that were taking over the running of the country.
literally raping it of its profits.
These people have been hurt by it.
The V.C.
told them the truth, that they lived under a corrupt government, which was true.
There's no doubt about it.
We know that now.
And a lot of people who knew it then tried to tell us, but we wouldn't listen.
They showed them the truth and convinced them that they were a better answer.
And all we did was go in with bigger and noisier things
We didn't appeal to their spirit at all.
And they could see through our greed like a clear glass.
It was easy to see.
I didn't know that then.
All I could see at that time was these people didn't care whether I died fighting for them or not.
And I don't like that.
I like to be appreciated a little bit.
That's the fallacy of the European people.
So I began to hate them.
The Arvin was a lousy excuse for an army that there ever was.
The harder it got, the worse he got.
Some units and some individuals were great.
There were two people that I knew that were fantastic, Colonel Lynn in canton and Captain Coy on my second tour.
He was a patriot.
He loved his country.
I don't know whether he got out or not.
I like to think he stole a helicopter, loaded his family up, and flew that thing out to an aircraft carrier and dumped it in the sea with the rest of them.
But I don't know.
Colonel Lynn was a fine man.
He was a good leader, and he was a patriot.
I don't know what happened to him.
His own people killed him.
That was after I left, thank God, because I would have gone berserk over that.
I really liked it.
I've only said that about three colonels in my entire life.
The other two were both Americans.
But as groups, they're lousy.
As individuals, some of them are pretty good.
The elite units, the Rangers, were fairly good, but they let that go to their heads and became more like Gestapo than anything else.
They say, I am the toughest, the meanest, and you give me all your chickens and your prettiest daughter, and I'm going to take them.
And they would.
So they were no better than the bad guys.
It was hard to tell who the good guy was and who the bad guy was.
I got fired on many, many times from Arvin units that were full of VC or NBA sympathizers.
Want something to drink?
